results.title: Les Enfants du Palais = Children of Justice
results.brief_description:
Judge Castaing in is charge of the Juvenile Delinquency Section of the Pantin area. Everyday he is faced with lost teenagers on the brink of criminality, irresponsible parents and an indifferent administration. Castaing is the archetypal ‘honest man’ who truly believes in his mission. Part judge, part father figure, the film shows a day in the life of a man who feels a father-like responsibility for every youth he is in charge of. All performances in ‘Les enfants du Palais’ ring so true that ultimately the spectator is compelled to share in Castaing’s anger and despair when one of his young charges is caught in a Police shoot-out. Filmed in documentary style (it is at times difficult to differentiate the actors from the real life participants), ‘Les enfants du Palais’ present a portrait of a system that has barely changed since the days of the infamous reformatories, and which is still unable to achieve its real mission: to save the children. See also: Les coeurs verts [X000390].

Credits: Director, Jean-Marie Perier ; music, Donovan.
Cast: Francois Perier, Martial Pautrel, Dani Graule, Simone Signoret (voice only).

results.title: Les Doigts Dans la Tete = Fingers in the Head
results.brief_description:
A young apprentice baker is fired by his boss. Since his room is included as part of his wages, and he cannot afford to leave, Chris decides to barricade himself in his room with a motley crue including a male friend, two girlfriends, a waitress and a Swedish hippie. Shot in black and white on 16mm with a largely amateur cast, this film is an excellent example of the young cinema of the 1970s.

Credits: Director, Jacques Doillon ; writers, Jacques Doillon, Philippe Defrance ; photography, Yves Lafaille.
Cast: Christophe Soto, Olivier Bousquet, Ann Zacharias, Roselyne Vuillaume, Gabriel Bernard, Martin Trevieres, Pierre Fabien, Francois Beranger.

results.title: Les Devoirs a la maison
results.creator_credit: Associated Television, Donald Carter and Michael Style
results.brief_description: From the series “French from France”, this French language training film teaches students pronunciation of a broad vocabulary in the familiar setting of doing homework. The family all assist Monique in turn, and then her friends call and they all work together on mathematical problems and the theme of an essay. Their discussion of their work repeating key nouns assists in the learning of the vocabulary.

results.title: Les Deux Anglaises et le Continent = Anne and Muriel
results.brief_description:
Based on Roche’s autobiographical second novel, ‘Two English Girls’ is an inverted version of Jules and Jim set in the Belle Epoque with two English girls, sisters of very different temperament, throughout their lives loving the same man - a Frenchman. Truffaut’s alter ego, Leaud, brings his persona of solitariness and passivity to the character of Claude at the apex of the triangle. Although both films are about wasted lives, ‘Two English Girls’ is sadder and more complex than Jules and Jim which is dominated by “Moreau’s charismatic capriciousness which spills all over the movie”, to quote Pauline Kael, giving it more vitality. ‘Two English Girls’, with its detached narration, is more introspective, dealing with emotions at one remove - ‘feelings about feelings’.

Credits: Director, Francois Truffaut ; writers, Francois Truffaut, Jean Gruault ; photography, Nestor Almendros ; music, Georges Delerue.
Cast: Jean-Pierre Leaud, Kika Markham, Stacey Tendeter.

results.title: Les Dernieres Vacances = the Final Holidays
results.brief_description:
In 1933, a couple on the verge of separation decide to sell the family country home. The mansion is a magic house, full of memories for their son Jacques and his cousins, specially Juliette. The teenagers decide to fight against the potential buyer, Gabard. Gabard is a seducer and is immediately smitten by Juliette. Faced with Gabard’s interest, the teenagers realise they are in love with each other.

Credits: Producer, Pierre Gerin ; director, Roger Leenhardt ; writers, Roger Leenhardt, Roger Breuil, Maurice Junod ; photography, Philippe Agostini ; music, Guy Bernard.
Cast: Odile Versois, Michel Francois, Pierre Dux, Renee Devillers, Jean d’ Yd.

results.title: Les Dames du Bois de Boulogne
results.brief_description:
Bresson’s second film, released in 1945 and scripted by Jean Cocteau. Made during the last days of the Occupation, the film combines the superficial glamour of the Parisian high society with the seething passions and jealousies that cause a spurned femme fatale, Helene, to seek her ex-lover’s humiliation. Through the climactic revelation of Helene’s deception, Bresson stages the deeper realisation of love’s redemptive power in an ending of truly magical transcendence. A landmark in cinema history… . Its influence on subsequent French cinema is far from exhausted” (David Thomson). The importance of ‘Les dames du Bois de Boulogne’ cannot be understated. Richard Roud, citing its formative influence on Antonioni, Demy, and Straub, among others, calls it ‘a universally seminal film.’ (In a recent interview, Godard provocatively called ‘Les dames du Bois de Boulogne’ the ‘only’ film of the French Resistance’, and Antonioni recently singled it out as a great influence on his own work.) Cocteau wrote the dialogue for this glistening melodrama of revenge, and though Bresson’s emerging style and his characteristic emphasis on entrapment, sacrifice, suffering and redemption are unmistakable, the world of ‘Les dames du Bois de Boulogne’ is also Cocteau’s, with its elegantly acid language, luxe setting, and Maria Casares’ piercing performance as a woman who arranges a bad marriage for the man who spurned her. Winner of the Louis Delluc prize for the most important French film of the year, ‘Les dames du Bois de Boulogne’ works perfectly as a razor-sharp conte cruel (Tom Milne). Reference: James Quandt. The poetry of precision: the films of Robert Bresson. Cinematheque Ontario. Online. http://www.bell.ca/filmfest/cinematheque/bresson.htm. Further reading: Film Comment. ‘Special Bresson’. May/June and July 1999

Credits: Producer, Raoul ploquin ; director, writer, Robert Bresson ; dialogue, Jean Cocteau ; photography, Phillipe Agostini ; music, Jean-Jacques Grunenwald ; decors, Max Douy.
Cast: Maria Casares, Elina Labourdette, Lucienne Bogaert, Paul Bernard, Jane Marchat.

results.title: Les Dames du Bois de Boulogne
results.creator_credit: Films Raoul Ploquin, Raoul Ploquin and Robert Bresson
results.brief_description: Made during the last days of the Occupation, the film combines the superficial glamour of Parisian high society with the seething passions and jealousies that cause a spurned femme fatale, Helene (Maria Casares) to seek her ex-lover’s humiliation (Paul Bernard). Helene seeks out two former friends, madame D (Lucienne Bogaert) and her daughter Agnes (Elina Labourdette), a talented dancer who has been forced into prostitution to support herself and her mother. After rescuing them from their desparate situation, Helene ensures that Jean meets Agnes, in the knowledge that he will fall in love and pursue her affections, urged on by Helene’s description of Agnes’s unattainability and chasteness. The inexorable logic of Helene’s scheme seems complete when Jean and Agnes are married, but through the revelation of truth Bresson delivers one of the most moving affirmations of the transcendent and redemptive powers of love. With dialogue written by writer/filmmaker Jean Cocteau, “Les Dames du Bois du Boulogne” was adapted to the screen by Bresson from an anecdote in Denis Diderot’s “Jacques Le Fataliste”. In French with English sub-titles.

results.title: Les Creatures = the Creatures
results.creator_credit: Mag Bodard, Philippe Dussart and Agnes Varda
results.brief_description:
A novelist and his pregnant wife go on holidays after he is horribly scarred during an automobile accident. He uses the time to complete his new novel and the local residents become models for his characters.

Credits: Producers, Mag Bodard, Philippe Dussart ; director, Agnes Varda ; writer, Agnes Varda ; photography, Willy Kurant, William Lubtchansky ; music, Pierre Barbaud.
Cast: Michel Piccoli, Catherine Deneuve, Eva Dahlbeck, Britta Patterson, Jacques Charrier, Lucien Bodard, Ursula Kubler, Nino Castelnuovo.

results.title: Les Cousins de 'la Constance': Episode 6
results.creator_credit: Marcel Degliame Fouche and Robert Mazoyer
results.brief_description:
In the village, the women wait nervously to hear reports about the fate of ‘La Constance’. While on its way back, the boat encounters a strong gale which causes the mine to start rolling about the deck.

Credits: Producer, Marcel Degliame Fouche ; director, Robert Mazoyer ; writer, Paul Guimard ; photography, Jean-Jacques Guyard ; music, Georges Delerue.
Cast: Jean Le Mouel, Claude Brosset, Lucien Barjon, Andree Tainsy, Jean-Marc Epinoux, Dominique Mac Avoy, Elina Labourdette, Jean-Pierre Kerien, Catherine Seynes.

results.title: Les Cousins de 'la Constance': Episode 5
results.creator_credit: Marcel Degliame Fouche and Robert Mazoyer
results.brief_description:
The first campaign of ‘La Constance’ has been marred by poor returns and lots of material damage. Jean is also increasingly worried that Anne is getting cold feet about becoming a fisherman’s wife. For the second campaign, Doctor Rey embarks on ‘La Constance’. Bad luck strikes again as the trawler picks up a WWII sea mine. While the crew disembarks on a life raft, the three Guillous stay on board to secure the mine.

Credits: Producer, Marcel Degliame Fouche ; director, Robert Mazoyer ; writer, Paul Guimard ; photography, Jean-Jacques Guyard ; music, Georges Delerue.
Cast: Jean Le Mouel, Claude Brosset, Lucien Barjon, Andree Tainsy, Jean-Marc Epinoux, Dominique Mac Avoy, Elina Labourdette, Jean-Pierre Kerien, Catherine Seynes.
